intro: Ophryoscleria microcarpa, commonly known as the small-fruited sand-verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Geraniaceae family and is characterized by its small, showy flowers that typically bloom in spring. The plant has a low-growing habit with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine, white hairs. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to arid environments, making it a hardy species in dry climates. Its ecological role includes providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a component of desert ecosystems.
